subject: Re: use of setUp and tearDown
msgSnippet: ... building the ... just ... That brings up an interesting question - can test methods in classes that contain static variables really be considered isolated,
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Elliotte Harold <elharo@m...> wrote:
> Neil Swingler wrote:
>
> > Kevin Lawrence already explained the difference between using
> > constructors and setUp. The constructor will be called when
building the
> > test suite so if you want your tests to be properly isolated, it is
> > safer to always perform the intialization work in setUp.
>
> I understand the difference. It's just that 90%+ of the time the
> difference doesn't matter. Unless you're doing something weird with
> static variables inside your constructors or something similar, the
> tests are still properly isolated when using constructors. setUp is
just
> a very weird thing that only matters in some strange corner cases. It
> consistently confuses new users who would be better served by simply
> ignoring it until they encounter one of the rare needs for it.
>
> --
> Elliotte Rusty Harold elharo@m...
> XML in a Nutshell 3rd Edition Just Published!
> http://www.cafeconleche.org/books/xian3/
> http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ISBN=0596007647/cafeaulaitA/ref=nosim

That brings up an interesting question - can test methods in classes
that contain static variables really be considered isolated, since one
test can accidentally change the static value needed by another test?
And if you're going to reinitialize the static variable in the
setUp() method every time, then what's the point in the variable being
static?

Alex
